title: 106_hr4080
content:
The "Home Office Worker Protection Act of 2000" applies the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 to home office employment. The Secretary of Labor will issue regulations applying the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 to workplaces in a residence where employees are engaged in home office employment or other types of employment. The regulations will include descriptions of different types of employment conducted in the residence, such as manufacturing, assembly, processing of goods for commerce, or employment involving regular exposure to toxic substances exceeding specified limits. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration regulations will address various types of employment in a residence, including exposure limits, inspection prohibitions, and actions for safety violations. Public participation in formulating implementing regulations is emphasized. The Secretary of Labor will implement regulations through notice and comment rulemaking to maximize public participation, including utilizing advance notice of proposed rulemaking and electronic means to reach affected workers and firms. The Secretary of Labor will implement regulations through notice and comment rulemaking, including utilizing advance notice of proposed rulemaking and electronic means to reach affected workers and firms. The regulations must be issued within 510 days of the enactment of the Act, with a 30-day effective date. The Act requires regulations to be issued within 510 days of enactment, with an effective date set 30 days after publication. AMENDMENT TO OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH ACT OF 1970. The Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 is amended to exempt home office employment from certain provisions, but employers must still report work-related injuries. The Secretary has the authority to impose sanctions for failure to report such injuries. Information and standards may be provided to employees and employers. The Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 is amended to exempt home office employment from certain provisions. The definition of home office employment is clarified as providing services using information technology in a residence. The Secretary of Labor will implement the amendments through rulemaking. The regulations under the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 will specify the application to workplaces in an employee's residence for home office employment and other types of employment. The Secretary will maximize public participation in formulating these regulations. The proposed rulemaking aims to reach affected workers and their employers through various means, including electronic, and provide a minimum of 60 days for public comment. If final regulations are not issued, the amendment to the Act and the requirement for regulations will become effective on the deadline for issuing final regulations. SEC. 4. RULE OF CONSTRUCTION.

This Act does not impact the existing instruction for home-based worksites until new regulations are issued.

SEC. 5. DEFINITION.

"Home office employment" refers to providing services using office equipment in the employee's residence.
